title: Bruce Woodgate
text:
Bruce E. Woodgate (1939 – April 28, 2014) was a <a href="United%20Kingdom">British</a>-born <a href="United%20States">American</a> <a href="aerospace%20engineer">aerospace engineer</a>, <a href="inventor">inventor</a> and <a href="astronomer">astronomer</a>, who worked at <a href="NASA">NASA</a>'s <a href="Goddard%20Space%20Flight%20Center">Goddard Space Flight Center</a> for forty years.
 He was the principal investigator of the <a href="Space%20Telescope%20Imaging%20Spectrograph">Space Telescope Imaging Spectrograph</a> (STIS), a <a href="spectrograph">spectrograph</a> and camera which was installed on the <a href="Hubble%20Space%20Telescope">Hubble Space Telescope</a> in 1997. Woodgate oversaw the design, development and construction of the STIS. Astronomers and other scientists have used the STIS to study and measure a wide range of <a href="light%20wavelength">light wavelength</a>s in deep space. Woodgate's invention has been called a "game changer" in the field of astronomy, allowing scientists to discover an "invisible high-speed collision" near SN 1987A, as well as new planets and <a href="black%20hole">black hole</a>s. A power failure knocked STIS offline in 2004, but it was repaired in 2009.
Aside his from his work as the principal investigator on STIS, Woodgate had also begun development on a new <a href="UV">UV</a> detector which counts <a href="proton">proton</a>s utilizing new <a href="nanotechnology">nano</a>-fabrication technologies. He was active in several new technologies such as photon-counting electron multiplying CCDs and integral field spectrographs designed for the direct detection of habitable exoplanets. He was honored with the <a href="NASA%20Distinguished%20Service%20Medal">NASA Distinguished Service Medal</a> and the Award of Merit from the <a href="Goddard%20Space%20Flight%20Center">Goddard Space Flight Center</a>. In addition to Goddard research, he was an avid sailor and an instructor in the Goddard Sailing Association.
Woodgate was born and raised in <a href="Eastbourne">Eastbourne</a>, <a href="East%20Sussex">East Sussex</a>, <a href="England">England</a>. He lived in a home on St. Anthony's Avenue in Eastbourne as a child and attended Eastbourne Grammar School. He began his career in astronomy and engineering at the <a href="Royal%20Greenwich%20Observatory">Royal Greenwich Observatory</a>, which was located at <a href="Herstmonceux%20Castle">Herstmonceux Castle</a> at the time. Woodgate then moved to London, where he earned a <a href="doctorate">doctorate</a> from <a href="University%20College%20London">University College London</a>. 
He moved to the United States, where he held positions at <a href="Columbia%20University">Columbia University</a>'s <a href="Goddard%20Institute%20for%20Space%20Studies">Goddard Institute for Space Studies</a>. In 1975, Woodgate joined the staff of NASA's <a href="Goddard%20Space%20Flight%20Center">Goddard Space Flight Center</a>, where he worked for the rest of his career.
Bruce Woodgate died on April 28, 2014, from complications from a series of strokes suffered during the previous month. He was 75 years old.
